Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and watery diarrhea for 2 days

Present Illness.Onset: On 19th, October, after consuming a meal at a local restaurant, Z. Walker began to experience nausea and abdominal discomfort.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain located in the lower abdomen, cramping in nature, constant with intermittent severe episodes. Symptoms have persisted for 2 days with progressive worsening. Vomiting and watery stools occurring multiple times a day. Fever recorded at home up to 38.5°C.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: General malaise and headache, consistent with primary symptoms. Unable to retain fluids or food.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Administered oral rehydration salts at home with minimal improvement. No relief from over-the-counter antiemetics.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Decreased mental alertness due to dehydration, poor sleep due to pain, reduced appetite, missed several meals, normal urination with increased frequency of loose stools, weight loss of 1 kg reported over the past 2 days.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally healthy prior to this incidence.
Past History.Disease History: No chronic illnesses. History of mild seasonal allergies.
Past History.Immunization History: Up to date with all scheduled vaccinations including MMR, DPT, Polio, and Hepatitis B.
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: No history of surgeries or major trauma.

Personal History.Living Habits: Maintains a balanced diet, active lifestyle with regular physical activity.
Personal History.Exposure History: No known exposure to industrial toxins or hazardous substances.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Father has a history of hypertension, mother has no significant medical history. No family history of similar gastrointestinal issues or genetic conditions.

Systematic Examination.Head and Organs: Normocephalic, atraumatic, pupils equal and reactive
Systematic Examination.Chest: Clear lung sounds bilaterally, heart sounds normal, no murmurs
Systematic Examination.Abdomen: Tender on palpation, particularly in lower quadrants, no guarding or rebound tenderness, active bowel sounds
Systematic Examination.Limbs: Normal range of motion, no deformities or tenderness
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert but lethargic, oriented to time and place, normal motor and sensory exam

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Stool culture pending, CBC showing elevated WBC at 15,000/mm3, Electrolytes showing mild hyponatremia at 134 mEq/L
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Patient's history of recent meal at a local restaurant, presenting symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, physical examination findings, and initial laboratory results.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Acute bacterial dysentery, cholera, acute hemorrhagic necrotizing enteritis, viral gastroenteritis, pufferfish poisoning, poliomyelitis

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Z. Walker, 11-year-old male, admitted with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea for 2 days. Initial lab results point towards bacterial food poisoning. Differential includes bacterial dysentery and viral enteritis. Treatment plan: IV fluid rehydration, broad-spectrum antibiotics (Ceftriaxone), antiemetics, and maintain NPO status.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Continued IV fluids, patient reports slight reduction in pain, vomiting less frequent, will continue current management and reassess tomorrow. Day 2: Patient shows improvement, pain reduced, fewer episodes of diarrhea, tolerating clear fluids, start oral rehydration.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed on 22nd October by Dr. Steven Miller, agrees with current treatment plan, emphasizes importance of stool culture results for specific antibiotic management.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: On 21th October evening shift, handover to Dr. Sarah Lee with updates on patient's stable condition and ongoing treatments.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient significantly improved by day 3 with reduction in symptoms, transitioning to oral antibiotics, planned discharge on 4th day if stable.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: IV fluids (Normal Saline), Ceftriaxone 1g IV Q24h, Antiemetics PRN, Monitor vital signs Q4H
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Stool culture and sensitivity, CBC with differential, Electrolytes panel

Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Fluctuating fever up to 38.5°C, down to 37.5°C after antipyretics, pulse and respiration initially elevated, stabilizing by day 2

Infectious Diseases.Name: Bacterial Food Poisoning
Infectious Diseases.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea and watery stools, accompanied by fever, etc.
Infectious Diseases.Differential Diagnosis: Acute bacterial dysentery, cholera, acute hemorrhagic necrotizing enteritis, viral gastroenteritis, pufferfish poisoning, poliomyelitis, etc.

qa_summary.question: According to the hospitalization records of Bridgewater City Hospital, summarize the present illness of Z. Walker.
qa_summary.answer: Z. Walker's present illness began on 19th October after consuming a meal at a local restaurant. He experienced severe abdominal pain, cramping, vomiting, and watery stools multiple times a day, along with a fever up to 38.5°C. He also had general malaise, headache, and was unable to retain fluids or food. Oral rehydration salts provided minimal improvement, and over-the-counter antiemetics offered no relief. His condition included decreased mental alertness, poor sleep, reduced appetite, missed meals, normal urination, increased frequency of loose stools, and a weight loss of 1 kg over the past 2 days.
